A lot of people seem to be commenting without watching this video. This is a very low risk situation as there is no centralized magma chamber rapidly increasing in pressure. Its unlikely that this caldera will ever be the site of a super volcanic eruption as the pressure is dispersed so widely compared to the previous eruption. Of course smaller eruptions are certainly possible, but my God, some of these comments are ridiculous.

Long Valley is not even a supervolcano and has not nearly produced the second most powerful eruption on the continent, at least five Yellowstone eruptions exceed the supervolcanic definition and none of long valley's do, there are at least nine actual supervolcanic systems in the US alone, almost all of which are either dead or dormant but nonetheless have produces as much as about 50 super eruptions in the past 40 million years alone, why do so called science channels never go beyond the basics on this subject?
Look at the maps of the ash fields from Yellowstone's last three major eruptions. Two of them look as though they really came from Long Valley.

Yellowstone isn't our only active supervolcano, there are others with eruptive history much more recently. Isn't the crust much thinner in this part of California than most places on earth? How much further down is the magma chamber feeding the satellite plumes?

The latest estimate of Long Valley Caldera magma chamber is 240 cubic miles, or 984 cubic km.  While Yellow stone has 432,000 cubic km near surface chambers. Mt. St. Helen had only less than 10 cubic km magma chamber prior to eruption.  The recent swarm of strong earthquakes along Eastern California Shear Zone (From Long Valley to Barstow) is just 100 miles south of Long Valley Caldera.  Be prepared.
